title: SkillStack
text:
If you’re using HTTPS, you can use Git’s credential helper to remember your GitHub credentials for each repository. Here’s how to do it:

Set the Git Credential Helper:

Open Terminal.
Run git config --global credential.helper osxkeychain to set the Git credential helper to osxkeychain, which tells Git to remember your credentials in MacOS’s keychain.

Change the Remote URL to Include Your Username:

In your project directory, run git remote set-url origin https://userb@github.com/userb/repo.git, replacing userb with your actual username and userb/repo.git with the actual path to your repository.
This tells Git to always use userb when pushing to this repository.

Enter Your Password When Prompted:

The next time you push, you’ll be asked for your password. Enter the password for userb.
Git will remember your username and password for this repository, so you won’t have to enter them again.

Repeat the Process for Each Repository:

You’ll need to repeat this process for each repository, replacing userb with the correct username for each one.


Now, Git will remember your credentials for each repository separately. If you’re still having trouble, let me know! I’m here to help.
